message.content:
cs.IT, cs.CR, cs.MM, cs.CV, cs.LG. 

The paper deals with the problem of authenticating content that has undergone legitimate editing as well as potential tampering attacks. This problem is relevant in a variety of applications, including multimedia and image processing, cryptography, and information theory. The paper characterizes and interprets the associated information-theoretic performance limits, which suggests that it belongs to the cs.IT (Information Theory) sub-category. The paper also discusses the use of Bernoulli and Gaussian cases, which suggests that it may also belong to the cs.CR (Cryptography and Security) and cs.MM (Multimedia) sub-categories. The paper's focus on image processing and authentication suggests that it may also belong to the cs.CV (Computer Vision) sub-category. Finally, the paper discusses the use of efficient layered authentication system constructions, which suggests that it may also belong to the cs.LG (Machine Learning) sub-category.
